description.summary: A three-legged creature with telescopic legs and a blowgun-like snout that shoots clay pellets to stun prey.
description.full: The Tripodero is a fearsome critter from American lumberjack folklore, distinguished by its three legs (hence the name) and unusual hunting method. The creature stands on its tripod-like legs near clay banks, using its hollow, telescopic snout as a blowgun to shoot clay pellets at prey. The compressed air propulsion stuns victims, which the Tripodero then eats. Associated with southwestern regions and clay bank habitats, it represents the creative absurdity of fearsome critter tradition - an impossible creature with an ridiculous hunting mechanism.

etymology.meaning: From 'tripod' - referring to its three-legged stance

abilities.description: Shoots clay pellets from snout to stun prey
Stands on three legs for stability

behavior.diet: Stunned prey hit by clay pellets

range.description: Southwestern United States in lumberjack folklore

folklore.beliefs: Never meant to be believed; absurd humor
